Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Integrated DC-DC Converters Using Thin-film Magnetic Power Inductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will develop integrated DC-DC power converters using magnetic thin-film power inductors. Currently, microprocessors and systems-on-chip (SoCs) are powered with board level voltage regulators assembled from discrete components. As supply voltages have scaled for digital integrated circuits (ICs), this power delivery paradigm has become increasingly inefficient, as power is delivered through the resistance of the power delivery network (PDN) at low voltages and high currents. In a typical case where 100 W is delivered at 1 V, 10% of the total power delivered may be wasted in the resistance of the PDN. The objective of this project is to commercialize power converters utilizing inductors with precisely engineered laminations of high permeability magnetic material. This will enable a significant improvement in power converter current density and subsequently enable power supplies for microprocessors and systems-on-chip to be down-converted in the same package, or even on the same die. This new class of integrated voltage regulators (IVRs) will provide as much as a 20% reduction in total power consumption for digital ICs by reducing resistive losses and enabling improved power management techniques.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is a reduction in power consumption for all digital computing platforms, ranging from smartphones to data centers. The total energy savings potential for this new class of technology is estimated at 15 billion kWh within the United States alone; this is equivalent to roughly 10 million metric tons of CO2 emissions. This technology will also significantly reduce the physical footprint for digital ICs, enabling a significant reduction in form factor for all classes of computing platforms. Voltage regulators utilizing integrated magnetic thin-film inductors will have cost and performance advantages over the other voltage regulator products that are commercially available. Therefore this technology is expected to have a sizeable impact on the $10 billion worldwide voltage regulator market. Furthermore, the integration of magnetic materials with Complementary Metal-Oxide-Semiconductor (CMOS) technology will facilitate advances in other magnetic based systems, such as magnetic filters, sensors and imagers. Likewise, the experience gained from commercializing a magnetic material process module with CMOS technology will lower the technological barriers for other forms of heterogeneous integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ferric has been successful in realizing the technical objectives of our NSF SBIR program. The team has successfully realized single-chip power converter product prototypes with peak conversion efficiency exceeding 90% for specific operating points. These single-chip switched inductor DC-DC converter products utilize Ferric’s proprietary thin-film magnetic core power inductors that have been transferred to a commercial CMOS foundry, TSMC. These power converters achieve a power conversion density exceed 50kW/in3, which is ~50x denser than the closest commercially available system. With successful realization of these power converter products, Ferric is seeing the onset of a broad commercial acceptance of Ferric’s technology in multiple forms: concerted planning efforts from customers towards the incorporation of Ferric power converter products within their systems, efforts to deploy Ferric’s thin-film power inductors for monolithic integrated voltage regulation, direct purchase and re-sell of Ferric power converter products or inquiry into license Ferric’s power converter circuit IP or process IP. This commercial activity indicates a positive market response to the technologies that Ferric has developed and then commercialized with support from this successful NSF SBIR effort. Based upon current trajectory of market acceptance and product design cycles, Ferric expects to be cash-flow positive by Q1, 2018 or sooner. We perceive this as a successful outcome for Ferric and the NSF SBIR program, which has been indispensable in the formation and success of Ferric. 

The integration of magnetic thin-films with CMOS manufacturing is a pioneering effort to provide improved energy efficiency of computing at the twilight of the Moore’s-Law era. Integrated magnetic thin-films enable dense, on-chip energy storage, which enables integrated voltage regulation. Integrated power conversion and management circuitry can exert greater control over the power supply in microprocessors and consequently, improved performance-per- watt. This “More-than-Moore” technology will provide immediate benefits in energy efficiency, cost and volume of next-generation computer processors and commercial benefits to the American semiconductor companies that exploit it. Integrated voltage regulators will provide energy efficiency gains as high as 50% in processors for all computing platforms, from high-end servers to smart phones. Annual datacenter power consumption is projected to reach 140 billion kilowatt- hours by 2020, costing American business $13B annually. With full market adoption, the IVR technology developed here will result in a direct annual energy savings of over 50 billion kWh nationally, and 150 billion kWh globally. IVRs will save American businesses over $5B in electricity costs and reduce annual global carbon emissions by over 200 million metric tons.
